That approach respects tradition and smaller-state voice while making outcomes track voters more closely and giving people in “safe” states a reason to believe their ballots matter.
statements.735: La forma de elegir al presidente debe sentirse justa y clara, porque cuando la gente cumple y trabaja duro, también espera que su voto cuente de verdad. En vez de borrar todo el sistema, un buen punto medio sería mantener el papel de los estados pero terminar con el “winner-take-all” y repartir los electores de manera proporcional, con reglas nacionales simples para conteo, auditorías y recuentos. Así se respeta el equilibrio regional sin dejar a millones en estados “seguros” pensando que su voto no vale, y se reduce el pleito eterno por reglas distintas en cada lugar. En pocas palabras: ni tanto que queme al federalismo, ni tan poco que siga pesando más la geografía que los votos.
statements.313: A healthy reform should keep the states’ role in certifying elections while making outcomes track the national will more closely, so fewer voters feel written off in “safe” states and fewer communities feel ignored. The clearest middle path is to end winner-take-all by allocating electors proportionally (or through a widely supported popular-vote compact), paired with uniform national standards for ballot access, recounts, and post-election audits that protect seniors and people with disabilities. Whatever the model, electors should be bound to the voters’ results, and the rules should be simple enough to earn trust even in the closest races.
statements.16: Presidential elections should work like a high-reliability system: transparent inputs, consistent standards, and an output that matches voter intent closely enough that most people accept the result even when they lose. A practical bridge is to keep the state-based framework but end winner-take-all by allocating electors proportionally (with binding electors and automatic recount triggers), paired with clear national baselines for audits, ballot access, and certification timelines. That would reduce swing-state distortion, preserve geographic legitimacy, and better align outcomes with the national popular will without forcing an abrupt constitutional overhaul.
statements.594: Presidential elections should be decided by rules that are easy to explain, hard to game, and make every voter feel their ballot truly matters, especially in places that rarely see campaign attention.
